body: From what I can see, gc only removes runs and here you haven't created any. Not sure if it's a bug or feature.

@festeh ah yes interesting point, i didn't pick up on that nuance. let me provide more details in that case, since the minimal example i provided has a solution (delete the folder from `.trash`) but the actual scenario under which i'm using mlflow isn't working. 

i'm using an AWS RDS database as my backend store and i've deployed a tracking server on an EC2 instance. 

```
>>> import mlflow
>>> MLFLOW_TRACKING_SERVER = # IP address of the tracking server
>>> mlflow_client = mlflow.tracking.MlflowClient(MLFLOW_TRACKING_SERVER)
>>> mlflow_client.list_experiments()
[<Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/0', experiment_id='0', lifecycle_stage='active', name='Default', tags={}>, <Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/5', experiment_id='5', lifecycle_stage='active', name='tests', tags={}>]
>>> experiment = mlflow_client.create_experiment('testing')
>>> mlflow_client.list_experiments()
[<Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/0', experiment_id='0', lifecycle_stage='active', name='Default', tags={}>, <Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/5', experiment_id='5', lifecycle_stage='active', name='tests', tags={}>, <Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/6', experiment_id='6', lifecycle_stage='active', name='testing', tags={}>]
>>> mlflow.delete_experiment('6')
>>> mlflow_client.list_experiments()
[<Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/0', experiment_id='0', lifecycle_stage='active', name='Default', tags={}>, <Experiment: artifact_location='s3://bucket/project/mlflow/5', experiment_id='5', lifecycle_stage='active', name='tests', tags={}>]
>>> experiment = mlflow_client.create_experiment('testing')
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/client.py", line 161, in create_experiment
    return self._tracking_client.create_experiment(name, artifact_location)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/tracking/_tracking_service/client.py", line 128, in create_experiment
    artifact_location=artifact_location,
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/tracking/rest_store.py", line 54, in create_experiment
    response_proto = self._call_endpoint(CreateExperiment, req_body)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/store/tracking/rest_store.py", line 32, in _call_endpoint
    return call_endpoint(self.get_host_creds(), endpoint, method, json_body, response_proto)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/rest_utils.py", line 137, in call_endpoint
    response = verify_rest_response(response, endpoint)
  File "/opt/conda/lib/python3.7/site-packages/mlflow/utils/rest_utils.py", line 103, in verify_rest_response
    raise RestException(json.loads(response.text))
mlflow.exceptions.RestException: RESOURCE_ALREADY_EXISTS: Experiment(name=testing) already exists. Error: (raised as a result of Query-invoked autoflush; consider using a session.no_autoflush block if this flush is occurring prematurely)
(psycopg2.errors.UniqueViolation) duplicate key value violates unique constraint "experiments_name_key"
DETAIL:  Key (name)=(testing) already exists.

[SQL: INSERT INTO experiments (name, artifact_location, lifecycle_stage) VALUES (%(name)s, %(artifact_location)s, %(lifecycle_stage)s) RETURNING experiments.experiment_id]
[parameters: {'name': 'testing', 'artifact_location': '', 'lifecycle_stage': 'active'}]
(Background on this error at: http://sqlalche.me/e/gkpj)
```

i'll rename the issue to be more descriptive.

rename.from: [BUG] mlflow gc does not appear to work

body:
Thank you @jeremyjordan and @festeh : [`mlflow gc`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/cli.html#mlflow-gc) is for cleaning up runs. Deleted experiments are moved to `.trash` folder in file store. In SQL store, the experiment is marked as `DELETED` but it is restorable.

`mlflow gc` can certainly be extended to clean up experiments as well. I am going to convert this to an enhancement. If you or someone else wants to submit a pull request to handle experiment GC (the original implementation came in as an open source contribution as well #2265). We recommend that you write up a quick proposal with options on how it would be implemented this, API/arguments, and backend implementations before you proceed with implementation.

cc: @dbczumar

ok i'll add a straw-man proposal

currently you can clean up deleted runs like
```
mlflow gc --backend-store-uri ‘sqlite:///path/to/file.db’ --run-ids 1,2,3,4
```
---
let's instead add another layer to the hierarchy to allow both:

1. cleanup of deleted runs
```
mlflow gc runs --backend-store-uri ‘sqlite:///path/to/file.db’ --run-ids 1,2,3,4

```

and 

2. cleanup of deleted experiments
```
mlflow gc experiments --backend-store-uri ‘sqlite:///path/to/file.db’ --experiment-ids 1,2,3,4
```

---

the implementation for deleting experiments would look very similar to the existing one for runs. just to confirm, it [looks like](https://github.com/mlflow/mlflow/blob/8e6b27dbc3370d9fc0e550d6bbaf00a7b7feb0be/mlflow/store/tracking/dbmodels/models.py#L141) hard deleting an experiment will also trigger a hard deletion of all corresponding runs. i think this is what we would want but would like to get confirmation that this is indeed desirable.

Hi, seems like I'm having this issue too, any progress on this enhancement? 
for now, as a workaround, deleting the relevant rows from the experiments table will allow me to create new experiments with previous names?

> Hi, seems like I'm having this issue too, any progress on this enhancement?
> for now, as a workaround, deleting the relevant rows from the experiments table will allow me to create new experiments with previous names?

Manually deleting the relevant rows from all required tables in the DB allowed me to reuse previously deleted names.

Looks like a significant bug, but I don't notice any updates. 
There is the same error in 1.14.* version.

Hi, 

I'm not familiar with SQL, I setup my mlflow server using
`mlflow server --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db --default-artifact-root s3://xxx/mlruns --host 0.0.0.0`
It creates `mlflow.db` file in my home directory. 

Then I tried `mlflow gc --backend-store-uri sqlite:///mlflow.db`. It doesn't seem to work. I still cannot reuse deleted experiment names. 

I want to try the SQL script provided from @mohammedayub44 , but I'm not sure how to use it. 
I copied the scipt to file `clean_db.sql`, and changed the the first line to `USE main;`, then I used command
`sqlite3 mlflow.db < clean_db.sql`, it shows
```
Error: near line 1: near "USE": syntax error
Error: near line 5: near "SELECT": syntax error
Error: near line 10: near "SELECT": syntax error
Error: near line 15: near "SELECT": syntax error
Error: near line 20: near "SELECT": syntax error
Error: near line 25: near "SELECT": syntax error
```
Could anyone let me know how to solve the problem in either way (mlflow gc or sql)?

> Thank you @jeremyjordan and @festeh : [`mlflow gc`](https://mlflow.org/docs/latest/cli.html#mlflow-gc) is for cleaning up runs. Deleted experiments are moved to `.trash` folder in file store. In SQL store, the experiment is marked as `DELETED` but it is restorable.
> 
> `mlflow gc` can certainly be extended to clean up experiments as well. I am going to convert this to an enhancement. If you or someone else wants to submit a pull request to handle experiment GC (the original implementation came in as an open source contribution as well #2265). We recommend that you write up a quick proposal with options on how it would be implemented this, API/arguments, and backend implementations before you proceed with implementation.
> 
> cc: @dbczumar

Hi @mparkhe. In what form do you expect proposals for this?
